title: 114_hr3284
content: The Act titled "Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015" establishes a patient registry for mesothelioma data collection and research under Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the United States. The registry will be used to track epidemiology, report on patient health information, describe disease incidence, facilitate research, and examine associated factors. The Secretary will establish a patient registry to gather data on mesothelioma in the United States, aiming to describe disease incidence, facilitate research, and examine associated factors like environmental and occupational influences. The registry will store information on demographics and make non-identifiable data accessible for research and prevention efforts. The patient registry established by the Secretary will collect and store information on mesothelioma in the United States, including demographics, risk factors, diagnosis markers, epidemiology, natural history, and prevention of the disease. The Secretary will consult with experts on mesothelioma, including epidemiologists, representatives of mesothelioma associations, health information technology experts, clinicians, and research scientists. The Secretary will consult with experts on mesothelioma, including epidemiologists, representatives of mesothelioma associations, health information technology experts, clinicians, and research scientists. The Secretary will also coordinate with other federal agencies to share information and analysis from the registry, and ensure public access while maintaining privacy. The Secretary will make information from the mesothelioma patient registry available to the public, ensuring privacy protections similar to HIPAA laws. A report outlining registry findings, future plans, and scope will be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress outlining findings, future plans, and scope of the mesothelioma patient registry. Additionally, a subsequent report will be provided within 4 years of the Act's enactment, detailing the development, information collected, and maintenance of the registry. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress detailing the development and maintenance of the mesothelioma patient registry, including the type of information collected, its use and availability, and the coordination of databases storing mesothelioma information.
